lessons.name: Getting and Succeeding in Interviews: Part 1
lessons.description: This video provides tips about résumés, LinkedIn, portfolio websites, GitHub, and references. This video then describes two approaches to getting interviews: active and passive.

lessons.name: Getting and Succeeding in Interviews: Part 2
lessons.description: This video describes typical interview processes. This video then offers company-specific interview-prep advice. Finally, this video provides advice for three kinds of interviews: iOS/Swift, data structures and algorithms, and system design. This video ends with a brief flex of budding Final Cut Pro mastery.

links.name: Over 150 iOS Interview Questions
links.definition: This is a collection by Paul Hudson of "over 150 of the top interview questions about iOS, Swift, UIKit, SwiftUI, and more".

links.name: Swift Algorithm Club
links.definition: This repo has "implementations of popular algorithms and data structures in" Swift.

links.name: Mural
links.definition: This is a visual collaboration tool sometimes used in system-design interviews.

links.name: Google Drawings
links.definition: This is a visual collaboration tool sometimes used in system-design interviews.

links.name: A Simple Framework For Mobile System Design Interviews
links.definition: This repo has "a simple framework for Mobile System Design interviews".

links.name: Typical Mobile System Design Interview Questions
links.definition: This repo has "exercises emulat[ing] typical interview scenarios using common system design questions".

keyTerms.name: REST
keyTerms.definition: A wildly popular client-server protocol that uses "verbs" like GET, PUT, POST, and DELETE. Supported by URLSession on Apple platforms.

keyTerms.name: gRPC
keyTerms.definition: A two-way, client-server protocol developed by Google. Transfers data economically, in binary form.

keyTerms.name: GraphQL
keyTerms.definition: A client-server protocol, developed by Facebook, that is similar to REST but that is more flexible for client developers and that is more economical in the data it transfers.
